in Cats
• Dermal (Skin) Irritation: The primary mechanism described for the foliage is contact dermatitis. If a cat brushes against the feathery leaves, it can cause skin irritation1.
• Gastrointestinal Toxicity: Ingestion of specific parts of the plant, particularly the berries, acts as a gastrointestinal irritant1.

• Berries: The berries are specifically highlighted as a source of internal toxicity. Eating them can lead to vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea1.

treatments.name: Dermal Decontamination (Bathing)
treatments.description: Since the foliage causes allergic dermatitis, the veterinarian or owner (under guidance) should bathe the cat using lukewarm water and a mild liquid dish soap to remove the irritating sap or plant material from the skin and fur.
treatments.notes:
This is the primary treatment for the skin irritation caused by brushing against the fern. It prevents further absorption and stops the cat from ingesting the toxin while grooming.
• Sources:1,2

treatments.name: Gastrointestinal Decontamination (Emesis & Activated Charcoal)
treatments.description: If the cat has ingested the berries (which contain the GI toxin), the veterinarian may induce vomiting (emesis) using prescription medications to remove the berries from the stomach. This may be followed by the administration of activated charcoal to bind any remaining toxins.
treatments.notes:
This step is taken if the ingestion was recent. Owners are advised not to induce vomiting at home (e.g., with hydrogen peroxide) as it can cause severe complications; this should be done in a clinic.
• Sources:3,2

treatments.name: Supportive Fluid Therapy
treatments.description: The administration of subcutaneous or intravenous fluids to correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
treatments.notes:
This is used if the cat has lost significant fluids due to the vomiting and diarrhea associated with berry ingestion.
• Sources:4,5

treatments.name: Symptomatic Medication (Antiemetics & Gastroprotectants)
treatments.description: The administration of medications to stop vomiting (antiemetics), soothe the stomach lining (gastroprotectants), and manage diarrhea.
treatments.notes:
Used to make the cat comfortable and prevent further fluid loss while the toxins pass through the system. A bland diet may also be prescribed for a few days to settle the stomach.
• Sources:5,2
